revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox book | name = Rossetti and His Circle | image = Rossetti and His Circle cover.gif | caption = Cover to the 1922 first edition of ''Rossetti and His Circle'' | author = [[Max Beerbohm]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States]] | language = English | genre = | publisher = [[Heinemann (book publisher)|William Heinemann]] | release_date = [[1922 in literature|1922]] | pages = |isbn= }} '''''Rossetti and His Circle''''' is a book of twenty-three [[caricatures]] by English [[Caricature|caricaturist]], essayist and [[Parody|parodist]] [[Max Beerbohm]]. Published in 1922 by [[Heinemann (book publisher)|William Heinemann]], the drawings were Beerbohm's humorous imaginings concerning the life of [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] and his fellow [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood|Pre-Raphaelites]], the period, as he put it, "just before oneself."Max Beerbohm, ''Rossetti and His Circle'', London: William Heinemann, 1922 The book is now considered one of Beerbohm's masterpieces.[http://www.nysoclib.org/collections/green/beerbohm_max.html Link] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219084148/http://www.nysoclib.org/collections/green/beerbohm_max.html |date=19 February 2012 }} Beerbohm on the [[New York Society Library]] website ==Beerbohm and Rossetti== Beerbohm returned to England from his home in [[Rapallo]] in Italy so that he could study photographs of the subjects he depicted in his caricatures. During the winter of 1917 he rented a cottage in the English countryside near the home of his friend [[William Rothenstein]] so that he could work on his Rossetti drawings. Every day, carrying his portfolio of drawings with him, Beerbohm walked across the snow to visit Rothenstein. "No wonder Max was nervous of leaving his Rossetti caricatures in an empty cottage... What a remarkable reconstruction of a period!" Rothenstein later wrote. Rossetti and the [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]] had captured Beerbohm's imagination. "In London, in the great days of a deep, smug, thick, rich, drab, industrial complacency," he wrote, "Rossetti shone, for the men and women who knew him, with the ambiguous light of a red torch somewhere in a dense fog. And so he still shines for me." Beerbohm's caricatures include [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] with his sister [[Christina Rossetti|Christina]], [[John Ruskin]], [[Algernon Charles Swinburne]], [[William Holman Hunt]], [[John Millais]] and [[George Meredith]]. In plate 22, [[Oscar Wilde]], on his 1882 lecture tour in America, describes the delights of the [[Aestheticism|Aesthetic Movement]] to a fascinated audience. This tour had been organised by [[Richard D'Oyly Carte]] to publicise the new [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] opera ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]''. Sir [[Hugh Walpole]] bequeathed Beerbohm's original watercolour artwork for ''Rossetti and His Circle'' to the [[Tate|Tate Collection]] in London in 1941.[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ArtistWorks?cgroupid=999999961&artistid=722&page=1 Link] The Beerbohm Collection at the [[Tate]] A special limited edition of 380 numbered copies bound in white cloth was also published in 1922. These were signed by Beerbohm. ==Contents== * Note (Beerbohm's Introduction to the Caricatures) * Frontispiece: Rossetti in Childhood. * 1. British Stock and Alien Inspiration. * 2. Rossetti's Courtship. * 3. A Momentary Vision that once Befell Young Millais. * 4. A Remark by Benjamin Jowett. * 5. Coventry Patmore at Spring Cottage. * 6. Ned Jones and Topsy. * 7. John Ruskin meets Miss Cornforth. * 8. Blue China. * 9. Woolner at Farringford. * 10. Ford Madox Brown patronised by Holman Hunt. * 11. The Small Hours in the Sixties at 16, Cheyne Walk. * 12. Gabriel and Christina. * 13. George Meredith's Hortation. * 14. William Bell Scott Wondering. * 15. Robert Browning introduces a Great Lady. * 16. George Augustus Sala with Rossetti. * 17. Swinburne and Mr. Gosse. * 18. Mr. Morley brings Mr. Mill. * 19. Mr. Leighton suggests Candidature. * 20. Mr. Watts, Mr. Shields, and Mr. Caine. * 21. The Touch of a Vanished Hand. * 22. Rossetti's Name is heard in America. ==The Plates== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Image ! Description |- valign="top" | [[Image:Rossetti-Frontis.jpg|300px]] | '''''Frontispiece. Rossetti in Childhood'''''
D. G. Rossetti, precociously manifesting, among the exiled patriots who frequented [[Gabriele Rossetti|his father]]'s house in [[Charlotte Street]], that queer indifference to politics which marked him in his prime and his decline. |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-1.jpg|300px]] | '''''British Stock and Alien Inspiration 1849'''''
First County Member/Holman Hunt: "Very clever no doubt" Second County Member/John Millais: "Full of wonderful ideas, but" First County Member/Holman Hunt; Second County Member/John Millais: "not to be trusted for one moment". ([[Benjamin Disraeli]] pondered by Tory MPs; Rossetti pondered by [[William Holman Hunt|Hunt]] and [[John Everett Millais|Millais]]) |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-2.jpg|300px]] | '''''Rossetti's [[Elizabeth Siddal|Courtship]]. Chatham Place, 1850–1860''''' |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-3.jpg|300px]] | '''''A Momentary Vision that once Befell Young [[John Everett Millais|Millais]] |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-4.jpg|300px]] | '''''The Sole Remark Likely to Have Been Made by [[Benjamin Jowett]] about the [[Oxford Union murals|Mural Paintings]] at the [[Oxford Union]]'''''
" And what were they going to do with the Grail when they found it, Mr. Rossetti?" |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-5.jpg|300px]] | '''''Spring Cottage, Hamstead, 1860'''''
[[Coventry Patmore]] preaches very vehemently to the Rossettis that a tea-pot is not worshipful for its form and colour but as a sublime symbol of domesticity. |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-6.jpg|300px]] | '''''[[William Morris|Topsy]] and [[Edward Burne-Jones|Ned Jones]], settled on the Settle in Red Lion Square.''''' |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-7.jpg|300px]] | '''''An Introduction'''''
[[Fanny Cornforth|Miss Cornforth]]: "Oh, very pleased to meet [[John Ruskin|Mr. Ruskin]], I'm sure.". |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-8.jpg|300px]] | '''''Blue China'''''
([[James Abbott McNeill Whistler|Whistler]] and [[Thomas Carlyle|Carlyle]]) |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-9.jpg|300px]] | '''''Woolner at [[Farringford House|Farringford]], 1857'''''
[[Emily Tennyson, Baroness Tennyson|Mrs. Tennyson]]: "You know, [[Thomas Woolner|Mr. Woolner]], I'm one of the most un-meddlesome of women; but – when (I'm only asking), when do you begin modelling his halo?" |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-10.jpg|300px]] | '''''[[Ford Madox Brown]] patronised by [[William Holman Hunt|Holman Hunt]]''''' |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-11.jpg|300px]] | '''''The Small Hours in the Sixties at 16, [[Cheyne Walk]]'''''
[[Algernon Charles Swinburne|Algernon]] Reading ''[[Anactoria]]'' to [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti|Gabriel]] and [[William Michael Rossetti|William]] |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-12.jpg|300px]] | '''''Rossetti, having just had a fresh consignment of "stunning" fabrics from [[Liberty & Co.|that new shop]] in [[Regent Street]], tries hard to prevail on his younger sister to accept at any rate one of these and have a dress made of it from designs to be furnished by himself.'''''
D. G. R. "What is the use, Christina, of having a heart like a singing bird and a water-shoot and all the rest of it, if you insist on getting yourself up like a pew-opener? " C. R. "Well, Gabriel, I don't know I'm sure you yourself always dress very quietly." |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-13.jpg|300px]] | '''''George Meredith's Hortation'''''
Rossetti insistently exhorted by [[George Meredith]] to come forth into the glorious sun and wind for a walk to Hendon and beyond |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-14.jpg|300px]] | '''''Mr. [[William Bell Scott]] wondering what it is those fellows seem to see in Gabriel''''' |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-15.jpg|300px]] | '''''[[Robert Browning|Mr. Browning]] brings a lady of rank and fashion to see Mr. Rossetti. |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-16.jpg|300px]] | '''''Rossetti in his worldlier days (circa 1866–1868) leaving the Arundel Club with [[George Augustus Sala]]'''''
Mr. Sala: "You and I, Rossetti, we like and we understand each other. Bohemians, both of us, to the core, we take the world as we find it. I give [[Joseph Moses Levy|Mr. Levy]] what he wants, and you give Mr. Rae and [[Frederick Richards Leyland|Mr. Leyland]] what they want, and glad we are to pocket the cash and foregather at the Arundel." |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-17.jpg|300px]] | '''''Riverside Scene'''''
[[Algernon Charles Swinburne]] taking his great new friend [[Edmund Gosse|Gosse]] to see Gabriel Rossetti. |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-18.jpg|300px]] | '''''[[John Morley, 1st Viscount Morley of Blackburn|Mr. Morley]] of Blackburn, on an afternoon in the spring of 69, introduces Mr [[John Stuart Mill]]'''''
"It has recently," he says, "occurred to Mr. Mill that in his lifelong endeavour to catch and keep the ear of the nation he has been hampered by a certain deficiency in well, in warmth, in colour, in rich charm. I have told him that this deficiency (I do not regard it as a defect) might possibly be remedied by you. Mr. Mill has in the press at this moment a new work, entitled 'The Subjection of Women.' From my slight acquaintance with you, and from all that I have seen and heard of your work, I gather that women greatly interest you, and I have no doubt that you are incensed at their subjection. Mr. Mill has brought his proof-sheets with him. He will read them to you. I believe, and he takes my word for it, that a series of illustrative paintings by you would" etc., etc. |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-19.jpg|300px]] | '''''The Man from Hymettus'''''
Mr. [[Frederic Leighton]] : "Think not for one moment, my dear Mr. Rossetti, that I am insensible to the charm of a life recluded, as yours is, from the dust of the arena, from the mire of the market-place. Ah no! I envy you your ivory tower. How often at some Council Meeting of the R.A. have I murmured within me that phrase of Wordsworth's, 'The world is too much with us'! But alas, in all of us there is a duality of nature. You, O felix nimium, are poet as well as painter. I, separated from my easel, am but a citizen. And the civistic passion yes, passion, dear Mr. Rossetti- restrains the instinct of the artist in me towards solitude, and curbs the panting of the hart in me for the water-brooks. I feel that I have, in conjunction with my colleagues, a duty to the nation. To improve the taste of the Sovereign, the taste of her ever-genial first-born and of his sweet and gracious consort, of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal of the faithful Commons, of the Judicial Bench, of those who direct the Army and Navy and Reserve Forces, of our merchant princes in Threadneedle Street and of our squires in the Shires, and through all these to bring light and improvement to those toiling millions on whom ultimately the glory of Great Britain rests all this is in me an ambition not to be stifled and an aspiration not to be foregone. You smile, Mr. Rossetti, yet I am not disemboldened to say to you now, as I have often wished to say to you, in the words of the Apostle Paul, 'Come over and help us!' Our President I grant you in confidence is not of all men the most enlightened. But I, in virtue of what is left to me of youth and ardour, conjoined with the paltry gift of tact, have some little influence at Burlington House. Come now! let me put your name down in our Candidates' Book." |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-20.jpg|300px]] | '''''Quis Custodiet Ipsum Custodem?'''''
[[Theodore Watts]]: "[[Hall Caine|Mr. Caine]], a word with you ! [[Frederic Shields|Shields]] and I have been talking matters over, and we are agreed that tonight and henceforth you must not and shall not read any more of your literary efforts to our friend. They are too what shall I say? too luridly arresting, and are the allies of insomnia." |- valign="top" | [[Image:rossetti-21.jpg|300px]] | '''''Mr. ___ and Miss ___ nervously perpetuating the touch of a vanished hand.'''''
([[Charles Augustus Howell]] and [[Rosa Corder]]). |- valign="top" | [[Image:max-oscar-1916.jpg|300px]] | '''''The Name of Dante Gabriel Rossetti is Heard for the First Time in the Western States of America.'''''
Time: 1882. Educational settings as place and/or subject in fiction form the theme of this catalogue of titles and authors. Organized alphabetically by the author's last name, the information is further divided by general school environments and those where the university, specifically, is the primary focal point. The list spans centuries and geographical boundaries, featuring Charlotte Brontë, Agatha Christie and Honore de Balzac as well as contemporary writers Curtis Sittenfeld, Joyce Carol Oates, and Donna Tartt. For those interested in learning more about the school/university in literature, references are included that provide a more academic study of the subgenre.

{{buzzword|date=January 2012}} '''Slow Design''' is a branch of the [[Slow movement (culture)|Slow Movement]], which began with the concept of [[Slow Food]], a term coined in contrast to ''fast food''. As with every branch of the Slow Movement, the overarching goal of Slow Design is to promote well being for individuals, society, and the natural environment. Slow Design seeks a holistic approach to designing that takes into consideration a wide range of material and social factors as well as the short and long term impacts of the design. ==Origin and meaning== Slow Design refers to the goals and approach of the designer, rather than the object of the design. In this way a Slow Design approach can be used within any [[design]] field. The term was probably first coined by Alastair Fuad-Luke in his 2002 paper "'Slow Design' - a paradigm for living sustainably?", in which Slow Design is seen as the next step in the development of [[sustainable design]], balancing individual, socio-cultural, and environmental needs. While Fuad-Luke focused on the design of physical products, the concept can be applied to the design of non-material things such as experiences, processes, services, and organizations. In fact, Slow Design may be seen as a path toward the [[dematerialization (economics)|dematerialization]] required for long-term sustainability as it takes into account the non-material nature of human well being and [[happiness]]. Beth Meredith and Eric Storm attempt to summarize the concept, stating:
Slow Design is a democratic and holistic design approach for creating appropriately tailored solutions for the long-term well being of people and the planet. To this end, Slow Design seeks out positive synergies between the elements in a system, celebrates diversity and regionalism, and cultivates meaningful relationships that add richness to life.
The editor and journalist [[Spencer Bailey]] has described Slow Design as “design that’s timeless and made to last, and done thoughtfully, with intent, and with care for our planet.”{{cite web|title=Spencer Bailey, editor, New York”|url=http://www.slow-words.com/spencer-bailey-editor-new-york/}} ==Current and future practice == {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2015}} Common qualities of Slow Design include: * Holistic – taking into account as many relevant short and long term factors as possible. * Sustainable – considering the [[Cradle to cradle design|cradle-to-cradle]] impacts and reducing harm as much as possible including the [[precautionary principle]]. * Elegant – finding the simplest and most concise solutions that provide the desired results. * Tailored – creating specific solutions that fit a particular situation. * Democratic – keeping the process and results accessible to those using and impacted by the design and to non-professionals. * Adaptable – developing solutions that will continue to work over time or that can be modified as needed. * Durable – making sure solutions can be maintained over time while minimizing the need for repairs and replacement. * Non-toxic – eliminating substances and processes that pollute or are toxic. * Efficient – minimizing waste of time, labor, energy, and physical resources. * Distinctive – promoting cultural, social, and environmental uniqueness and diversity. Slow design is still a relatively new concept of design thinking, and its implications are yet to be fully developed and defined. It could evolve in the following ways: * Longer design processes with more time for research, contemplation, real life impact tests, and fine tuning. * Design for manufacturing with local or regional materials and technologies or design that supports local industries, workshops, and craftspeople. * Design that takes into account local or regional culture both as a source of inspiration and as an important consideration for the design outcome. * Design that studies the concept of natural time cycles and incorporates them into design and manufacturing processes. * Design that looks at longer cycles of human behavior and sustainability. * Design that takes into account deeper well being and the findings of [[positive psychology]]. == See also == {{Portal|Design}} * [[Slow movement (culture)|Slow Movement]] * [[Systems thinking]] * [[Design thinking]] * [[User-centered design]] == References == {{Reflist|refs= * Fuad-Luke, Alistair. [http://www.arts.ulster.ac.uk/artm/courses/jdmm/emotion/slow-des.pdf "'Slow Design' - a paradigm for living sustainably?"]. arts.ulster.ac.uk. 2002. Retrieved 2011-1-20. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717141318/http://www.arts.ulster.ac.uk/artm/courses/jdmm/emotion/slow-des.pdf |date=July 17, 2011 }} * Meredith, Beth and Storm, Eric. [http://www.create-the-good-life.com/slow_design.html "Slow Design - A Conscious Approach to Creating Well Being"]. Create-The-Good-Life.com. 2009. Retrieved 2011-1-20. }} * [http://www.slowdesign.org Slow Theory: A paradigm for living sustainably?.] October 2004. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110122025834/http://observatory.designobserver.com/entry.html?entry=3947 “In Praise of Slowness”.] Design Observer. January 2006. * [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/31/garden/31slow.html “The Slow Life Picks Up Speed”.] ''The New York Times''. January 2008. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401230508/http://www.slowlab.net/CtC_SlowDesignPrinciples.pdf The Slow Design Principles: A new interrogative and reflexive tool for design research and practice] Strauss, C. and Fuad-Luke, A. July 2008 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061122183856/http://www.experientia.com/blog/uploads/2006/10/slow_design_background.pdf Slow + Design | Abstracts + Manifesto: Slow approach to distributed economy and sustainable sensoriality.] July 2008. * [http://www.create-the-good-life.com/slow_life_design.html “Slow Life Design: Embracing Your Inner Slow Life Designer”.] Create-The-Good-Life.com. October 2009. == External links == {{Design}} [[Category:Design]] [[Category:Software design]] [[Category:Industrial design]] [[Category:Slow movement]]

{{Multiple| {{COI|date=March 2018}} {{tone|date=March 2018}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use British English|date=February 2012}} [[File:Stephen Farthing.png|thumb|Stephen Farthing in 2009]] '''Stephen Farthing''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|RA}} (born 16 September 1950) is an English painter and writer on [[art history]].
==Education== Stephen Farthing grew up in London and earned a bachelor's degree from [[Saint Martin's School of Art]] in 1973 and a master's degree in painting from the [[Royal College of Art]], London in 1976.<ref name="royalacademy1">{{cite web|url=http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/academicians/painters/stephen-farthing-ra,175,AR.html |title=Stephen Farthing RA - Painters - Royal Academicians - Royal Academy of Arts |publisher=Royalacademy.org.uk |date=1950-09-16 |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref> In the final year of his master's program, Farthing won a scholarship to study at the [[British School in Rome]] for one year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.purdyhicks.com/artists/stephenfarthing/ |title=Purdy Hicks Artists Index |publisher=Purdyhicks.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref>
==Life and career== Since his return from Italy in 1977, Farthing has had one-man shows in the UK, Brazil, Uruguay, Mexico, Australia, Japan, and the United States.<ref name="royalacademy1"/> Farthing's work featured in the 1989 [[São Paulo Art Biennial|São Paulo Biennale]] and that same year he served as the Artist in Residence at the [[Hayward Gallery]] in London. He also won prizes in the John Moores Liverpool Exhibition on eight separate occasions between 1976 and 1999.<ref name="royalacademy1"/>
Farthing was elected as a member of the [[Royal Academy of Arts]] in 1998.<ref name="royalacademy1"/> Farthing's work is in the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)]] and he also showed at the [[Tate Britain]] in 2006 as part of a project called "Drawing from Turner," that he designed and curated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/britain/exhibitions/drawingfromturner/ |title=Drawing from Turner |publisher=Tate |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref> Farthing also painted large murals for the [[Cleveland Browns]] Football Club in Cleveland, Ohio (2004) and [[Aston Villa]] Football Club in Birmingham, UK (2008).<ref>http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~1405273,00.html</ref><ref name="Stephen Farthing">{{cite web |url=http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/marco.htm |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Stephen Farthing |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193759/http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/marco.htm |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Stephen Farthing's teaching career began at [[Canterbury College of Art]] (1977–1979) where he was a lecturer of painting. He went on to teach at the [[Royal College of Art]] (1980–1985) before becoming the Head of Painting and later the Head of Fine Art at [[West Surrey College of Art and Design]] (1985–1989).<ref name="royalacademy1"/> Farthing spent the next ten years at [[Oxford University]] serving as the Ruskin Master at the [[Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art]]. He was also made a Professorial Fellow of Oxford's [[St Edmund Hall]] (1990–2000). Upon leaving the university in 2000, Farthing was made a professor emeritus of St Edmund Hall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seh.ox.ac.uk/users/stephenfarthing |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Seh.ox.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-04-10}}</ref>
Farthing moved to New York in 2000 to become the Executive Director of the [[New York Academy of Art]] and led the Academy until he became the Rootstein Hopkins Research Chair of Drawing at the [[University of the Arts London]] in 2004, a position he held until 2017.<ref name="chelsea.arts.ac.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.arts.ac.uk/research/research-staff/a-z/professor-stephen-farthing/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413150046/http://www.arts.ac.uk/research/research-staff/a-z/professor-stephen-farthing/ |archivedate=13 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Farthing has published extensively. Most known for his authorship of ''1001 Paintings You Must See Before You Die'' and ''501 Great Artists''. He also authored the Intelligent Person's Guide to Modern Art, published in 2000 in addition to numerous academic essays and journal articles.<ref name="chelsea.arts.ac.uk"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stephenfarthing.com/biblio.htm |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Stephen Farthing |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208064936/http://stephenfarthing.com/biblio.htm |archivedate=8 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Stephen Farthing continues to live and work in both the United Kingdom and the United States.
==Work== [[File:Step9.gif|thumb|alt=Stephen Farthing.|''Louis XV Rigaud'' (1975), [[Walker Art Gallery]]]]''
Farthing described his work in a 2005 interview, saying "I have dined with the devil in terms of becoming a modern artist. I have taken hold of history, tried to understand it—and then used and abused it."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=196599&sectioncode=26 |title=Draw the line at copying? Not him | General |publisher=Times Higher Education |date=2005-06-10 |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref>
Farthing's work reflects his education, personal experience and perspective on historical events that have captured his imagination. After spending a period of study at the Cité Internationale des Arts in Paris while a student at the [[Royal College of Art]], Stephen Farthing inadvertently fell upon what one could later describe as a postmodernist relationship with history.<ref>Randy Lerner, "The Fourth Wall," in Stephen Farthing: The Fourth Wall, London: Purdy Hicks, 2009, p. 5.</ref> In Paris, he painted an interpretation of [[Hyacinthe Rigaud]]'s portrait of [[Louis XV]] that as a student won him a prize at the John Moores Exhibition in Liverpool, today this painting stands as an early example of British post modernist painting.<ref name="Stephen Farthing"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/collections/20c/farthing.aspx |title='Louis XV Rigaud', Stephen Farthing - Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool museums |publisher=Liverpoolmuseums.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228131607/http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/collections/20c/farthing.aspx |archivedate=28 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In the late 1980s and early 1990s whilst showing with Edward Totah in London, Farthing showed works that positioned Latin American vernacular culture within a modernist idiom and classicism within the vernacular.
During the 1990s, he reinvented history painting as a viable contemporary narrative taking on subject matters as diverse as the [[Battle of Trafalgar]], swagger portraiture, and the topographical mapping of cities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/mcewan.htm |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Stephen Farthing |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193821/http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/mcewan.htm |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/122406/pro_122406079.shtml |title=Cleveland Browns owner getting his kicks from English football | Lubbock Online | Lubbock Avalanche-Journal |publisher=Lubbock Online |date=2006-12-24 |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref> His most recent work makes explicit a theme that has consistently sat between Farthing and his audience, the "narrative" and "text".
[[File:MH.Trafalgar.2.20.06.jpg|thumb|center|upright=2.0|alt=Hands of Fate. |''Hands of Fate'', ([[Battle of Trafalgar]])]] [[File:GetAttachment-2.aspx.jpeg|thumb|left|alt=Stephen Farthing.|''The Backstory: Boucher'' (2009)]]
Farthing commented that his work is, "not this thing about 'Oh, let's let the audience make up their mind what it is'…" but about "degrading it on purpose so it becomes not more ambiguous, but less what it was in the first place."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lynnparr.co.uk/articles/Farthing.pdf|title=Stephen Farthing : Marginally Out of Control|publisher=Lynnparr.co.uk|accessdate=2013-11-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193753/http://www.lynnparr.co.uk/articles/Farthing.pdf|archivedate=2 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Toward the end of 2009, Farthing had his first one-person show at the Purdy Hicks Gallery in London where, for the first time, he showed the "back-story" paintings.<ref>Randy Lerner, "The Fourth Wall," in Stephen Farthing: The Fourth Wall, London: Purdy Hicks, 2009, p. 7.</ref> The "back-story" paintings are a series of images painted with a text in reverse sitting on the picture plane between the audience and the image. The text tells us what is going on not in the picture but behind it, so compromising and at the same time informing the image with text. His technically very skilled paintings all seem to be grounded on one guiding principle - that what we see will always be always conditioned by what we know.
In November 2010, Farthing became the second living Royal Academician to be featured in the "laboratory" series of one man shows at the Royal Academy of Arts London. "The Back Story," featured an epic 30 foot painting of the Atlantic ocean.<ref>{{cite web|last=Royal Academy of Arts|title=Artists' Laboratory 02: Stephen Farthing RA, The Back Story|url=http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/artists-laboratory/artists-laboratory-02-stephen-farthing-ra-the-back-story,342,RAL.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301044735/http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/artists-laboratory/artists-laboratory-02-stephen-farthing-ra-the-back-story,342,RAL.html|archivedate=1 March 2014|work=Press Release|accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Chelsea Space|title=Stephen Farthing's Ultra Marine Painting|url=http://www.chelseaspace.org/blog/archives/272|work=Atlantic Ocean|accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref>
Farthing's work as a painter sits midway between the conservative and the cutting edge between a classical and radical painting. [[File:Atlantic by Stephen Farthing.png|thumb|center|upright=2.0|alt=Atlantic.|''The Atlantic'' (2006), photographed at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]], December 2010.]]
==Bibliography==
*Ruskin and Art Education 1836-1993, Review of the Pre-Raphaelite Society, no.3, Autumn.1993 *The Knowledge, The Artist's Eye, Essay Arts Review, paintings of SE1.1995 *Cornelia Hesse Honegger, exhibition catalogue, interview with Dr Stephen Simpson, edited by Paul Bonaventura, published by Locus +, Newcastle.1997 *''In a Valley of the Restless Mind'', Hilary Davis, Enitharmon,1997 {{ISBN|1-870612-97-3}}. *''International Minds'', front cover by Stephen Farthing *''Instructions For Use'', English translation of ''Mode d'emploi'', Editions, Jannink, Paris, {{ISBN|2-902462-48-4}}. *''Mode d'emploi'', Stephen Farthing, Edition Jannink, funded by the British Council, Paris, 1999 {{ISBN|2-902462-44-1}}, *''New Contemporaries'', catalogue essay with Paul Bonaventura, 1999 *''The Higher Education Journal, Vol. 10, March Fine Art, The Cinderella Subject, Stephen Farthing, 1999 *''Intelligent Persons Guide to Modern Art'', Stephen Farthing, Duckworth, London,2000 {{ISBN|0-7156-2944-1}}. *''British School at Rome Centenary'', edited by Andrew-Wallace Hadrill, chapter "Post War Art 1945-75", 2002 {{ISBN|0-904152-35-9}}. *''Will Barnet: in his own words'', edited by Sandra April and Stephen Farthing, NYAA, 2004 New York. *''A Curriculum for Artists'', edited by Stephen Farthing and Paul Bonaventura, University of Oxford & NYAA, 2004 {{ISBN|0-9538525-3-9}}. *''Dirtying the Paper Delicately'', University of the Arts, London. 2005 *Jerwood Drawing Prize, Drawing: The Bigger Picture, catalogue essay, 2005, {{ISBN|0-948327-20-0}}. *''Short Stories about Painting'', edited by Jeffrey Dennis, essay, The Unpaintable, Art Space Gallery 2005, {{ISBN|0-9549623-2-X}}. *''1001 Paintings You Must See Before You Die'', 2006, edited by Stephen Farthing. [[Cassell (publisher)|Cassell]]. 2006 {{ISBN|978-1-84403-563-2}}, {{ISBN|1-84403-563-8}}. *''Writing on Drawing'', 2008, edited by Steven Garner, with essay by Stephen Farthing and introduction by Anita Taylor. Published by Intellect, {{ISBN|978-1-84150-200-7}}. *''501 Great Artists, A Comprehensive Guide to the Giants of the Art World'', 2008, USA Publisher: Barron's Educational Series. New Zealand Publisher: Penguin. {{ISBN|0-7641-6133-4}} . {{ISBN|978-0-7641-6133-9}}.

{{Italic title}} '''''Ten Stories About Smoking''''' is the debut short story collection by writer [[Stuart Evers]].<ref name=newstates>{{cite web|last=Preston|first=Alex|title=Ten Stories About Smoking|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/books/2011/02/stories-smoking-evers-short|publisher=New Statesman|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|last=Walton|first=James|title=A Page in the Life: Stuart Evers|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/8373442/A-Page-in-the-Life-Stuart-Evers.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=25 April 2012|location=London|date=10 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news|last=Segal|first=Francesca|title=Ten Stories About Smoking by Stuart Evers|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/apr/02/stuart-evers-ten-stories-smoking-review|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 April 2012|location=London|date=2 April 2011}}</ref><ref name=picador>{{cite web|title=Stuart Evers|url=http://www.picador.com/authors/Stuart-Evers|publisher=Picador|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=edinburgh>{{cite web|title=Stuart Evers|url=http://www.edbookfest.co.uk/writers/stuart-evers|publisher=Edinburgh International Book Festival|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = The Birds of America | title_orig = The Birds of America; from original drawings by John James Audubon | translator = | image = Audubon Birds of America.jpg | caption = The cover shows a Louisiana heron,
[[Tricolored heron|''Egretta tricolor'']] (now called tricolored heron) | author = [[John James Audubon]] | illustrator = John James Audubon | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = | series = | subject = Birds – North America; Birds – pictorial works | genre = | publisher = | pub_date = 1827–1838 | media_type = | pages = 435 | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = [[Library of Congress Classification:Class Q -- Science#QL Zoology|QL674]] .A9 1827 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Birds of America''''' is a book by [[natural history|naturalist]] and painter [[John James Audubon]], containing illustrations of a wide variety of [[List of birds of the United States|birds of the United States]]. It was first published as a series in sections between 1827 and 1838, in [[Edinburgh]] and London. Not all of the specimens collected in the work were collected by Audubon himself, some were sent to him by [[John Kirk Townsend]] who had collected them on [[Nathaniel Jarvis Wyeth]]'s 1834 expedition with [[Thomas Nuttall]]. Mearns, B. & R. ''John Kirk Townsend: Collector of Audubon’s Western Birds and Mammals'' (2007). 'Narrative of a Journey Across the Rocky Mountains to the Columbia River' by John Kirk Townsend The work consists of 435 hand-coloured, life-size [[Printmaking|prints]], made from [[engraving|engraved]] plates, measuring around {{convert|39|by|26|in|cm}}. It includes images of six now-[[Extinction|extinc]]t birds: [[Carolina parakeet]], [[passenger pigeon]], [[Labrador duck]], [[great auk]], [[Eskimo curlew]], and [[Heath hen|pinnated grouse]].{{cite web|url=http://web4.audubon.org/bird/boa/ExtinctBirds.html|title=Birds Extincted since Audubon's time|first=National Audubon|last=Society|website=web4.audubon.org}} Art historians describe the quality of Audubon's work as being of high and printed with "artistic finesse." The plant-life backgrounds of some 50 of the bird studies were painted by Audubon's assistant [[Joseph Mason (artist)|Joseph Mason]] but he is not credited for his work in the book.Burt, DeVere. [http://www.ruthven.com/ruthven/CJR-SpringGrove/go "The Joseph Mason Project, Historic Spring Grove Cemetery and Arboretum"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222103914/http://www.ruthven.com/ruthven/CJR-SpringGrove/go |date=22 December 2015 }}. Ruthven.com website. Accessed 17 December 2015. He shot many specimen birds as well as transporting and maintaining supplies for Audubon.{{Cite news|url=http://historydetectives.nyhistory.org/2013/03/blast-from-the-past-everyone-needs-a-good-assistant/|title=Blast From the Past: Everyone Needs a Good Assistant|date=8 March 2013|work=History Detectives|access-date=27 November 2017|language=en-US}} Audubon also authored the companion book ''Ornithological Biographies''.{{Cite web|url=http://digital2.library.pitt.edu/collection/audubons-birds-america?f%5B0%5D=mods_typeOfResource_ms:%22text%22|title=Audubon's Birds of America|website=digital2.library.pitt.edu|access-date=27 November 2017}} ==Early publication history== [[File:1 Wild Turkey.jpg|thumbnail|left|Plate 1 by [[John James Audubon]] depicting a wild turkey, ([[Wild turkey|''Meleagris gallopavo'']]).]] About 1820, around the age of 35, Audubon declared his intention to paint every bird in North America.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/26/arts/antiques-central-park-s-winged-tenants-by-audubon.html|title=Central Park's Winged Tenants, By Audubon|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 December 2003}} In his bird art, he mainly forsook oil paint, the medium of serious artists of the day, in favour of [[watercolours]] and pastel crayons (and occasionally pencil, charcoal, chalk, [[gouache]], and pen and ink). As early as 1807, he developed a method of using wires and threads to hold dead birds in lifelike poses while he drew them. [[File:AudubonCarolinaParakeet2.jpg|thumbnail|upright|Audubon Carolina parakeet ([[Carolina Parakeet|''Conuropsis carolinensis'']])
now extinct]] In 1823, Audubon went to [[Philadelphia]] and New York, looking for financial support using [[Subscription business model|subscription]]s to enable him to publish his artwork. He sold the copper engraving plates through on a subscription basis in North America and Europe. Those subscribed obtained five plates at a time. Each subscriber received prints of three smaller birds, a larger bird and a mid-sized bird. The prints were produced from 1827 to 1838 that cost each subscriber around $1,000.This is equivalent to $24,600 in 2015{{Cite web|url=http://www.in2013dollars.com/1838-dollars-in-2015|title=1838 dollars in 2015 {{!}} Inflation Calculator|website=www.in2013dollars.com|language=en|access-date=27 November 2017}} It is thought that no more than 120 complete sets exist today. Each set consists of 435 individual plates that are based upon the original paintings. Each plate was engraved, printed, and hand colored by Robert Havell of London. While William Lizars, of Edinburgh, engraved the first ten plates, Havell actually finished some of those. Audubon often found support lacking. As a result, in 1826, he set sail for the United Kingdom with 250 of his original illustrations, looking for the financial support of subscribers and the technical abilities of [[Engraving|engraver]]s and printers.{{cite web|url=http://www.nls.uk/exhibitions/audubon/influence#lizars|title=Audubon and men of influence|publisher=}} After exhibiting his drawings in [[Liverpool]] and [[Manchester]], he journeyed to Edinburgh, where he met the accomplished engraver [[William H. Lizars]]. Lizars engraved up to ten of the first plates but was unable to continue the project when his colourists went on strike.{{cite web|url=http://www.liv.ac.uk/artgall/audubon/birds_of_america.htm|title=Victoria Gallery & Museum|publisher=University of Liverpool|work=liv.ac.uk}} In 1827, Audubon engaged the noted London animal engraver [[Havell family|Robert Havell Jr.]], and his father, [[Havell family|Robert Havell Sr]]. Havell Jr. oversaw the project through to its completion in 1838. [[File:Zenaida macrouraAWP17AA.jpg|thumb|upright|frameless|Carolina pigeon,
[[Mourning dove|''Zenaida macroura'']] (now called mourning dove).]] [[File:Aphelocoma coerulescens & Diospyros virginiana (Audibon).png|thumbnail|upright|''Aphelocoma coerulescens'' (Florida jay)]] The original edition of ''The Birds of America'' (sometimes called the Havell Edition{{cite web|url=http://www.minniesland.com/study_Havell_Edition.html|title=Original Audubon Prints - Antique Natural History Prints - Books - Havell - Bien - Imperial Folio - Bird and Animal Prints|work=minniesland.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619135214/http://www.minniesland.com/study_Havell_Edition.html|archivedate=19 June 2010|df=dmy-all}} after its printer, and sometimes called the [[Book size|"Double Elephant Folio"]], because of its size) was printed on handmade paper 39.5 inches tall by 28.5 inches wide. The principal printing technique was [[intaglio printing|copperplate]] etching, but engraving and [[aquatint]] were also used. Colorists applied each color in assembly-line fashion (over fifty were hired for the work).Rhodes, 2004, pp. 273, 389. Audubon funded the costly printing project through a pay-as-you-go subscription. From 1826 to 1829, he travelled around the UK and to Paris, lecturing on ornithology and frontier American life in an effort to entice wealthy patrons to subscribe to the series of prints. Subscribers included the French king [[Charles X]], the British queen [[Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen]], [[George Spencer, 2nd Earl Spencer|Lord Spencer]], and, later, the Americans [[Daniel Webster]] and [[Henry Clay]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/03/books/antiques-rarae-aves-audubon-at-auction.html|title=Rarae Aves: Audubon At Auction|newspaper=The New York Times|date=3 March 2000}} Prints were issued in sets of five every month or two in tin cases{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/25/arts/antiques-vibrant-birds-of-america-via-germany.html|title=Vibrant Birds Of America, Via Germany|newspaper=The New York Times|date=25 June 2004}} and each set usually included one very large bird, one medium-sized bird, and three small birds. The plates were published unbound and without any text to avoid having to furnish free copies to the public libraries in England. It is estimated that not more than 200 complete sets were ever compiled. An accompanying text, issued separately, was written by Audubon and the Scottish naturalist and ornithologist [[William MacGillivray]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/nature-online/science-of-natural-history/biographies/william-macgillivray/|title=William MacGillivray|work=nhm.ac.uk}} and published in five volumes in [[Edinburgh]] between 1831 and 1839, under the title ''Ornithological Biography, or, An account of the habits of the birds of the United States of America''. The additional cost of the five volumes of text brought the total cost of plates and text to about $1000. After the folio edition was completed, Audubon decided to produce a more affordable edition and employed a lithographer from Philadelphia named J. T. Bowen. Bowen and his team created a smaller [[Octavo#Size|Royal Octavo]] edition, which was issued to subscribers in seven volumes and completed in 1844 after selling 1,199 sets.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} Five more octavo editions were completed through 1877. The octavo edition used the text of the Ornithological biography but increased the number of plates to 500, separating some birds which had originally appeared together. Some new drawings were included, mostly by John Woodhouse though Audubon and members of Bowen's team also contributed.{{cite web |url=http://www.audubonhouse.org/audubon/octavo/bowen.cfm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703042004/http://www.audubonhouse.org/audubon/octavo/bowen.cfm |archivedate=3 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.abirdshome.com/Audubon/VolI/00000.html|title=The Registry Of Nature Habitats - Audubon Birds of America - Publisher's Preface|work=abirdshome.com}} The Bien Edition (after [[chromolithography]] pioneer Julius Bien), was a full-sized reissue published in 1858 by Roe Lockwood in New York under the supervision of Audubon's youngest son, John Woodhouse Audubon.{{cite web|last=Flynn|first=Ron|title=The Bien Edition / The Project, Quality, Errors and Market Value|url=http://www.auduboninfo.net/articles/BIEN%20ESSAY.htm|accessdate=30 September 2012}} Due in part to the Civil War, the edition was never finished; only 15 parts of the 44 part series were completed. This edition consisted of 105 plates and included none of the original text.{{cite web|url=http://www.audubongalleries.com/guide/guide.php |title=Audubon Galleries Original Audubon Books and Prints |publisher=Audubongalleries.com |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} Fewer than 100 subscriptions were sold, making this edition rarer than other early editions.{{cite web|author=Ron Flynn |url=http://www.auduboninfo.net/articles/audubon_story.htm |title=About Audubon and His Octavo Edition Prints |publisher=Auduboninfo.net |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} Audubon's practice of obtaining his subjects has been described as:“Audubon used what we like to call today as the barrel-of-the-shotgun method...After he killed the birds, he would use a complex system of wires and strings to position the birds. Previous artists would draw the birds in a stiff position, but Audubon was different. He drew the birds in dynamic ways, by positioning them how he would observe them in the field.” ==Public exhibitions== [[File:3 Prothonotary Warbler restored.jpg|thumb|upright|Prothonotary warbler ([[Prothonotary warbler|''Protonotaria citrea'']]) in plate 3]] A full 8-volume, double-elephant folio version is on public display in the Audubon Room at the Harlan Hatcher Graduate Library at the [[University of Michigan, Ann Arbor]]. This, the first book purchased by the University, was bought in 1839 for $970 (equivalent to ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|970|1839|r=-4}}}} in {{Inflation-year|UK}}), at the time an amazing sum. The entire volume of 435 plates is also available for viewing online at the University of Michigan's website.{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umich.edu/audubon-room/pictureit-rare-book-reader|title=PictureIt Rare Book Reader|work=umich.edu}} Since 1992, the [[Louisiana State University]] Libraries have hosted "Audubon Day," a semi-annual public showing of all four volumes of LSU's copy of the ''Birds of America.'' The set formerly belonged to one of the original subscribers, the [[Hugh Percy, 3rd Duke of Northumberland|Duke of Northumberland]], and was purchased with a grant from the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in 1964. In recent years, the event has drawn more than 200 visitors. It was profiled in a 2011 ''[[Wall Street Journal]] ''article titled "The Joys of Slow Looking."{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703421204576327750299277440|title=Birds of America by John James Audubon at Hill Memorial Library at Louisiana State University-The Joys of Slow Looking|work=Wall Street Journal|author=Willard Spiegelman|date=19 May 2011}} In 2003, the [[University of Pittsburgh]], which owns a complete collection of ''Birds of America'' that had been recently restored and preserved by the Etherington Conservation Center, mounted a major exhibition of 62 selected plates and other materials in its [[Frick Fine Arts Building#University Art Gallery|University Art Gallery]]. Following this, the university constructed an exhibit case on the ground floor of the school's [[Hillman Library]] to continuously display a rotating selection of plates to the public. Single plates have been exhibited for two weeks at a time in plate number order.{{cite web | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/a/audubon/about.html | title=Audubon at Pitt | publisher=University Library System, University of Pittsburgh | year=2008 | accessdate=22 August 2011}} In 2007, the university undertook a project to digitize every plate from ''Birds of America'', as well as Audubon's ''Ornithological Biography'', and, for the first time, presented the complete set for public viewing through one site on the internet.{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/a/audubon/|title=Audubon's Birds of America|work=pitt.edu}}{{cite news | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08064/862193-42.stm | title=Audubon's 'Birds' now in flock on one Web site | first=Bob | last=Hoover | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=4 March 2008 | accessdate=22 August 2011}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/art-architecture/2017/11/14/John-James-Audubon-falcons-birds-of-prey-National-Aviary-Hillman-Library/stories/201711150043|title=Free Audubon Day includes prints, lectures|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|access-date=29 November 2017|language=en}} This event, called "Audubon day" was first conducted in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.pitt.edu/Audubon_Day_2012|title=Pitt’s University Library System Hosts Second Annual Audubon Day|publisher= University of Pittsburgh News|website=www.news.pitt.edu|language=en|access-date=29 November 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://pittnews.com/article/64902/news/birders-flock-to-audubons-art/|title=Birders flock to Audubon's art - The Pitt News|date=2 November 2015|work=The Pitt News|access-date=29 November 2017|language=en-US}} In 2007 the book was the subject of an exhibition by the [[Teylers Museum]] in [[Haarlem]], which owns a copy it ordered from the original subscription.{{cite web|url=http://www.vogelsxxl.nl/tentoonstelling.php|title=Teyler's 2007 exhibition website|date=3 November 2007|publisher=Vogelsxxl.nl|accessdate=10 December 2010}} To commemorate the book's record-breaking sale, the museum decided to display its copy (for which the museum eventually paid 2200 [[guilder]]s—a fortune at the time—during the years 1827–1838) until January 2011.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} All of Audubon's and Mason's known extant watercolors preparatory for ''Birds of America'' are housed at the [[New-York Historical Society]] in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.minniesland.com/study_Audubon_Art_Prints_Steiner.htm|title=Original Audubon Prints - Antique Natural History Prints - Books - Havell - Bien - Imperial Folio - Bird and Animal Prints|work=minniesland.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111025136/http://www.minniesland.com/study_Audubon_Art_Prints_Steiner.htm|archivedate=11 November 2010|df=dmy-all}} The [[Stark Museum of Art]] in [[Orange, Texas]] owns and exhibits John James Audubon's personal copy of ''Birds of America''.{{cite web |url=http://kogt.com/Stark%20Audubon.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216212421/http://kogt.com/Stark%20Audubon.htm |archivedate=16 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }} In 2010 the [[North Carolina Museum of Art]] began a five-year exhibition of its restored four-volume set purchased for the state by Governor [[William Alexander Graham]] in 1846.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncartmuseum.org/exhibitions/audubon|title=Exhibitions|work=ncartmuseum.org}} [[Liverpool Central Library]] currently has a copy of ''Birds of America'' on display in a glass case, with its pages turned weekly,{{cite web|url=http://www.sevenstreets.com/city-living/refurbishment-liverpool-central-library/ |title=Rekindling Liverpool Central Library |publisher=Sevenstreets.com |accessdate=24 January 2013}} as well as being displayed through an [[interactive kiosk]], allowing readers to view the contents close-up without damaging the original copy using an Evoke Ev5 Kiosk.{{cite web|url=http://www.evoke-kiosks.co.uk/news/the-book-and-the-kiosk.aspx|title=The book and the kiosk|work=evoke-kiosks.co.uk}} One of the original books was bought by [[Laurance Spelman Rockefeller]], who had each plate individually framed. They are all hanging throughout the public areas of the Woodstock Inn, in Woodstock, Vermont, which he built in 1969.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} Paisley Museum and Art Gallery, in [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]] Scotland has the four volume elephant folio of Birds of America.{{Cite web|title = Prize possessions on show at Paisley museum|url = http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/prize-possessions-show-paisley-museum-6819388|website = dailyrecord|accessdate = 3 December 2015}} The [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow|Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons]] in Glasgow, Scotland holds one volume which is on display in the library, together with an interactive version.{{Cite web|title = Doors Open Day 2015|url = http://libraryblog.rcpsg.ac.uk/2015/08/28/doors-open-day-2015/|website = College Library|accessdate = 3 December 2015}} ==Collections and archives== Though individual prints are commonly available, only one hundred twenty complete sets are known to exist. One complete copy of ''The Birds of America'' exists as part of [[The Darlington Collection]] at the [[University of Pittsburgh]].{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/art-architecture/2013/11/17/University-of-Pittsburgh-exhibits-Audubon-prints/stories/201311170047|title=Pitt exhibits Audubon prints|publisher=Pittsburgh Post Gazette|last=Pitz |first=Marylynne |date= 16 November 2013|access-date= 27 November 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://audubon.pitt.edu/|title=Audubon's Birds of America at the University of Pittsburgh|website=audubon.pitt.edu|access-date=27 November 2017}} Another complete collection is housed with [[Meisei University]] in Tokyo, Japan.{{Cite web|url=http://birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp/|title=Meisei University Birds Of America, Meisei University|last=|first=|date=|website=birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp|access-date=27 November 2017}} ''The Birds of America'' is on permanent display in [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College's]] Watkinson Library, and was owned by the engraver, Robert Havell. It was donated to the College in 1900 by Gurdon Wadsworth Russell, an 1834 graduate of Trinity.{{Cite web|url=http://www.trincoll.edu/NewsEvents/NewsArticles/pages/Birds.aspx|title=Trinity College is Nest for Birders|last=Webmaster|website=www.trincoll.edu|access-date=1 October 2016}} [[Toronto Public Library]] also holds a copy; originally a four-volume set, it was unbound to preserve the individual plates which have been digitized in the library’s [https://www.torontopubliclibrary.ca/search.jsp?Erp=20&N=38537+4294831200&Ntt=Audubon&view=grid Digital Archive] and stored in custom-made boxes in the Toronto Reference Library.{{Cite web|url=http://omeka.tplcs.ca/virtual-exhibits/exhibits/show/audubon/tpl-copy|title=Birds of America at the Toronto Public Library · John J. Audubon’s Birds of America · TPL Virtual Exhibits|website=omeka.tplcs.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-11}} Another complete copy of the prints, bound in 17 volumes, belongs to the [[Library of Parliament]] in [[Ottawa]], Canada.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/john-james-audubon-birds-library-parliament-digitize-1.3838474|title=Library of Parliament digitized John James Audubon bird masterpiece {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en-US}} ==Recent sales== In March 2000 Sheikh [[Collecting practices of the Al-Thani Family|Saud Al-Thani of Qatar purchased]] a copy of ''The Birds of America'' at a [[Christie's]] auction for $8.8 million, a record for any book at auction.{{cite web|url=http://www.artandantiquesmag.com/2009/02/call-of-the-wild/|title=John James Audubon's 'Birds Of America' Sells for $8.8 Million|work=Art & Antiques Magazine}} In December 2010, ''[[The Economist]]'' magazine estimated that, adjusted for inflation, five of the ten highest prices ever paid for printed books were paid for copies of ''The Birds of America''.{{cite news| url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2010/12/books | work=The Economist | title=Book value | date=8 December 2010}} Of the 120 copies known to survive, only thirteen are held in private collections.{{cite web|last=Collett |first=Mike |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/40547140 |title=Rare 'Birds of America' book fetches $11.5M at auction|publisher=Today.msnbc.msn.com |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} In March 2000 the Fox-Bute copy sold at Christie's, New York, for $8,802,500.[[BBC]], 9 September 2010, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11242275 World's most expensive book goes back on sale]{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/shakespeare-first-edition-breaks-sothebys-record-with-16328m-sale-407861.html|title=Shakespeare first edition breaks Sotheby's record with £2.8m salet|work=The Independent}} In December 2005 an unbound copy, the Providence Athenaeum Set, sold, again at Christie's, New York, for $5.6 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704635704575604751410902906|title=Collectors Circle as 'Birds of America' Comes to Auction at Sotheby's|author=Ellen Gamerman|date=26 November 2010|work=Wall Street Journal}} On 6 December 2010, a complete copy of the first edition was sold in London at [[Sotheby's]] for £7,321,250 (approximately $11.5 million){{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-07/aristocrats-seeking-cash-boost-119-million-old-master-auctions-in-london.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Scott | last=Reyburn | title=‘Birds of America' Book Fetches Record $11.5 Million | date=7 December 2010}} during the sale of Magnificent Books, Manuscripts and Drawings from the Collection of Frederick, [[Frederick Fermor-Hesketh, 2nd Baron Hesketh|Second Lord Hesketh]]. The winning bid was a record auction price for a printed book and was placed by London-based art dealer [[Edward Tollemache#Courtier|Michael Tollemache]], who outbid three others during the auction. According to the [[provenance]] details reported by the auction house, the copy's original owner was [[Henry Witham]] of Durham, listed as subscriber 11 in Audubon's ''Ornithological Biography''; the first volume of the set bears a presentation inscription from Witham's wife, dated 24 June 1831.{{cite web| publisher= [[Sotheby's]] |url= http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/2010/magnificent-books-manuscripts-and-drawings-from-the-collection-of-frederick-2nd-lord-hesketh-l10413/overview.html| title= Lot 50: The Birds of America; from original drawings by John James Audubon. London: published by the author, 1827–1838 | accessdate=10 December 2010}} Lord Hesketh had bought the copy from a descendant of Witham at a [[Christie's]] auction on 3 July 1951, paying £7,000. On 20 January 2012 a complete copy of the first edition was sold by heirs of the [[William Bentinck, 4th Duke of Portland|Fourth Duke of Portland]] at Christie's, New York, for $7.9 million. The buyer was identified only as "an American collector who bid by phone." The sale brought to 120 the number of copies known to have survived – 107 in institution collections and 13 in private hands.{{cite news |title=Audubon's ‘Birds' sells for $7.9M |agency=Associated Press |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-01-20/news/30649241_1_species-first-edition-audubon |newspaper=New York Daily News |date=20 January 2012 |accessdate=1 May 2012}} ==Plates== File:61 Great Horned Owl.jpg|Great horned owl
([[Great horned owl|''Bubo virginianus'']]) File:86 Black Warrior.jpg|Harlan's hawk in plate 86 File:11 Bird of Washington.jpg|Bird of Washington, possibly a rare species or a misidentified juvenile [[Bald eagle]] File:151 Turkey Buzzard.jpg|

 [[c:User:Mturtle/The_Birds_of_America|Gallery of the rest of the plates.]] ==Textiles== [[File:Audubon fabric.jpg|thumb|Furnishing fabric, from [[Lancashire]], 1830s]] In 1830s, immediately after the publication, several plates were used as a basis for the design of a series of roller-printed furnishing fabric, produced in [[Lancashire]], United Kingdom.{{cite web|title=Furnishing fabric, Lancashire, 1830s, Victoria and Albert Museum, CIRC.305-1956|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O115037/furnishing-fabric/|accessdate=23 February 2012}} ==See also== * [[List of most expensive books and manuscripts]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs={{cite web| url= http://lccn.loc.gov/06018534 | title= The birds of America; from original drawings | publisher= [[Library of Congress]] | accessdate= 10 December 2010}} }} ==Bibliography== * Rhodes, Richard (2004). ''John James Audubon: The Making of an American''. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. {{ISBN|0-375-41412-6}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://audubon.pitt.edu ''Birds of America'' at the University of Pittsburgh] — ''with high resolution images of all 435 double elephant folios.'' * [http://birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp/ Meisei University: ''Birds of America''] — ''the complete sets of 435 plates of drawings, with the accompanying five volumes of textbooks.'' * {{Internet Archive short film|id=gov.archives.arc.55178|name=John James Audubon: The Birds of America (1986)}} *[https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Popular_Science_Monthly/Volume_31/September_1887/Sketch_of_J._J._Audubon Popular Science Monthly/Volume 31/September 1887/Sketch of J. J. Audubon] {{natural history}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Birds Of America, The}} [[Category:Ornithological handbooks]] [[Category:Fine illustrated books]] [[Category:Birds of North America|.]] [[Category:Birds of the United States|.]] [[Category:1827 books]] [[Category:English books]] [[Category:Birds in art]]

'''The Book Collector''' is a [[London]] based journal that deals with all aspects of the book.
It is published quarterly and exists in both paper and digital form. It prints independent opinions on subjects ranging from typography to national heritage policy, from medieval libraries to modern first editions. It has run series on Unfamiliar Libraries, Literary and Scientific Autographs, Author Societies, Contemporary Collectors and many other subjects.
== History == An earlier series that preceded the Book Collector, was the ''Book Handbook''. <ref>{{Citation | author1=Horrox, Reginald, (ed.) | title=Book handbook : an illustrated guide to old and rare books | publication-date=1951 | publisher=Berks | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/13274412 | accessdate=23 November 2017 }}</ref> ''The Book Collector'' was launched by the novelist [[Ian Fleming]] in the same year, 1952, that he wrote the first [[James Bond]] novel, ''[[Casino Royale (novel)|Casino Royale]]''.<ref>{{Citation | author1=British Library | title=The pleasures of Bibliophily: Fifty Years of The book Collector: An Anthology | publication-date=2003 | publisher=British Library ; New Castle, Del. : Oak Knoll Press | isbn=978-1-58456-097-5 }}</ref>
The journal has had only four editors since it was founded. After the death in 1965 of John Hayward, the friend and muse of [[T.S. Eliot]], it was edited for fifty years by [[Nicolas Barker]], sometime publisher and first head of conservation at the [[British Library]]. In 2015 he stepped down and James Fergusson, founding obituaries editor of ''[[The Independent]]'', 1986-2007, took his place.
Essays about book collecting by Geoffrey Keynes in the Book Collector has been published in a compilation volume. <ref>{{Citation|author1=Keynes, Geoffrey Sir, 1887-1982| title=To Geoffrey Keynes: articles contributed to "The Book Collector" to commemorate his eighty-fifth birthday|publication-date=1972|work=The Book Collector|isbn=978-0-903482-00-4}}</ref>
== Publication == ''The Book Collector'' publishes four times a year in March, June, September and December. Each issue consists of 192pp and is sent to subscribers by airmail, where appropriate. Subscribers also have digital access to every issue of ''The Book Collector'', as printed, since its first appearance in 1952 and to its predecessor ''Book Handbook'', which was published in twenty-eight numbers between 1947 and 1951. There is no restriction for libraries and other institutions on the number of digital users. ''The Book Collector'''s website holds its complete archive, indexed.
==Publication details== *{{Citation | title=The Book collector | publication-date=1952 | publisher=London, The Collector Ltd | issn=0006-7237 }}
==See also== * [[Book trade in the United Kingdom]] * [[Books in the United Kingdom]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.thebookcollector.co.uk/ Official website.]
{{books}} {{Italic title}}

revision.text:
[[File:The Swan Princes - Anne Anderson.jpg|thumb|''The Swan Princes'' by [[Anne Anderson (illustrator)|Anne Anderson]]]]
'''The Six Swans''' (in German : ''Die sechs Schwäne'') is a German [[fairy tale]] [[Grimm's Fairy Tales|collected]] by the [[Brothers Grimm]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surlalunefairytales.com/authors/grimms/49sixswans.html |title=Household Tales by Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm with Author's Notes translated by Margaret Hunt |publisher=SurLaLune Fairy Tales |date=2006-10-15 |accessdate=2016-06-05}}</ref> as tale number 49. [[Andrew Lang]] included a variant in ''[[The Yellow Fairy Book]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mythfolklore.net/andrewlang/047.htm |title=THE SIX SWANS from Andrew Lang's Fairy Books |website=Mythfolklore.net |date=2003-07-12 |accessdate=2016-06-05}}</ref> It is [[Aarne–Thompson]] type 451: the brothers who were turned into birds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/grimmtales.html |title=Grimm Brothers' Children's and Household Tales (Grimms' Fairy Tales) |publisher=Pitt.edu |date=2016-04-09 |accessdate=2016-06-05}}</ref> Other tales of this type include [[The Magic Swan Geese]], [[The Seven Ravens]], [[The Twelve Wild Ducks]], [[Udea and her Seven Brothers]], [[The Wild Swans]], and [[The Twelve Brothers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surlalunefairytales.com/sevendwarfs/other.html |title=Tales Similar To Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs |publisher=SurLaLune Fairy Tales |date= |accessdate=2016-06-05}}</ref>
==Synopsis==
[[File:Heinrich Vogeler - Illustration Die sechs Schwäne.jpg|thumb|Illustration by [[Heinrich Vogeler]]]]
A King gets lost in a forest, and an old woman helps him, on the condition that he marry her beautiful daughter. The King has a bad feeling about this but accepts anyway. He has six sons and a daughter from his first marriage, however, and fears that the children will be targeted by his new wife; so he sends them away and visits them in secret.
The new queen and now [[stepmother]], who has learned witchcraft from her mother, finds out about her stepchildren and decides to get them out of her way. She sews six magical shirts and goes to the hidden castle where the children are hidden for safety, then tosses the shirts over the boys and transforms them into [[swan]]s.
The brothers can only take their human forms for fifteen minutes every evening. They tell their still human younger sister that they've heard of a way to break such curses: she must make six shirts out of [[nettle]]s and can't make a sound for six years or the spell will never be broken. The girl agrees to do this and runs away, hiding in a hunter's hut and dedicating herself solely to gathering the nettles and sewing in silence.
Years later, the King of another country finds the girl doing this, is taken by her beauty, and takes her into the court with the intention of making her his queen. However, the King's snobbish mother hates her and does not consider her fit to be a Queen. When she gives birth to their first child, the wicked mother-in-law takes away the child and accuses the queen of killing and eating him, but the King refuses to believe it.
The young Queen gives birth to two other children, but twice again the mother-in-law hides them away and falsely claims that she has killed and eaten her babies. The King is unable to keep protecting her, and unable to properly defend herself, the queen is sentenced to be [[Death by burning|burned at the stake]] as a witch. All this time, she has held back her tears and her words, sewing and sewing the nettle shirts no matter what.
On the day of her execution, the Queen has all but finished making the shirts for her brothers. Only the last shirt misses a left arm. When she is brought to the stake she takes the shirts with her and when she is about to be burned, the seven years expire and the six swans come flying through the air. She throws the shirts over her brothers and they regain their human form, though the youngest prince's left arm remains a wing due to the missing sleeve.
The queen is now free to speak, and she can defend herself against the accusations. She does so with the support of her brothers. In the end, the evil mother-in-law is the one who is burned at the stake as punishment.
==Adaptations== * ''[[Daughter of the Forest]]'', the first book of the [[Sevenwaters trilogy]] by [[Juliet Marillier]], is a detailed retelling of this story in a medieval [[Celts|Celtic]] setting. A young woman named Sorcha must sew six shirts from a painful nettle plant in order to save her brothers (Liam, Diarmuid, Cormack, Connor, Finbar and Padriac) from the witch Lady Oonagh's enchantment, remaining completely mute until the task is finished. Falling in love with a British lord, Hugh of Harrowfield alias "Red", complicates her mission.
* An episode from the anime series ''[[Grimm's Fairy Tale Classics]]'',<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.showtime.jp/app/detail/contents/l15vid200206901088352/ |title=新グリム名作劇場 第10話 六羽の白鳥 | アニメ | 動画はShowTime (ショウタイム) |website=Web.archive.org |date=2013-06-22 |accessdate=2016-06-05 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622031028/http://www.showtime.jp/app/detail/contents/l15vid200206901088352/ |archivedate=June 22, 2013 }}</ref> starring [[Mitsuko Horie]] as the Princess (here named Elise), [[Toshiko Fujita]] as the witch, [[Hideyuki Hori]] as the prince, [[Ishizuka Unsho]] as the king, and [[Koichi Yamadera]], [[Taku Takemura]], [[Masami Kikuchi]], and Keiichi Naniwa as the brothers. This plot differs in some parts from the Grimm's version, especially in the second part of the story. In the anime, the evil stepmother-queen kills her husband and puts a spell on his children to gain total control of the kingdom like in the original, but later she takes up the role of the Princess/Queen's evil mother-in-law and leaves Elise's baby son (her only child) in the forest. The swan-brothers find their nephew the forest and keep him alive, plus they're stuck in their swan forms all day/night long (though they still can speak) until their sister breaks the curse and they give her the baby back. Elise finishes the garments in time, therefore the youngest is not left with a swan wing in the end. When the wicked stepmother is exposed as the witch ''and'' as the one who framed Elise at the end, she uses her magic in an attempt to escape but then accidentally catches fire from Elise's pyre and burns to death.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JKPtShfBadw |title=GFTC - The Six Swans |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=2014-05-28 |accessdate=2018-01-11}}</ref>
* [[Paul Weiland]]'s episode "The Three Ravens" of [[Jim Henson]]'s television series ''[[The Storyteller]]'' is another retelling of this classic tale. After the queen dies, an evil witch ensnares the king and turn his three sons into [[raven]]s. The princess escapes and must stay silent for three years, three months, three weeks and three days to break the spell. But after she meets a handsome prince, this is suddenly not so easy, for her stepmother has killed her father and remarried - to the prince's father. But when the witch attempts to burn the princess at the stake, the ravens attack her and she accidentally sets fire to herself instead, instantly turning into ashes. Her death almost fully reverses the spell, but the princess breaks her silence three minutes too soon, and her youngest brother subsequently keeps one wing forever.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.angelfire.com/me3/muppets/Story_ThreeRavens.html |title=The Storyteller Presents The Three Ravens |website=Angelfire.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-05}}</ref>
* The novel ''Birdwing'' by Rafe Martin follows the youngest prince, human but with a wing instead of his left arm, as he grows up with this "deformity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rafemartin.com/bk_birdwing.html |title=Rafe Martin-Birdwing |website=Rafemartin.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-05}}</ref>
* ''Moonlight'' features a thirteen-year-old princess named Aowyn who loses her mother to a mysterious illness, and is charged with protecting her father and her six brothers from the conniving of a witch bent on taking the throne. This retelling is written by Ann Hunter and set on the Summer Isle, an alternate Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ann Hunter |url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/20620664-moonlight |title=Moonlight by Ann Hunter — Reviews, Discussion, Bookclubs, Lists |website=Goodreads.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-05}}</ref>
